Hi,
	I also follow GP.

	I've been planning for some time to address this random crossover 
deficiency of GP (and I think I even discussed it here?).  I was going to 
go with an evolving (arbitrary) labels approach, rather than an innovation 
numbers, but they are not very different really.

	Some GP systems do use speciation (and in fact I would say they have tried 
a wider variety of approaches than the TWEANN community, possibly because 
they have had less success :)).

	The GP field suffers a bit from clashing ideologies, e.g. there are 1/2 
doz competing GP approaches out there and not all the practitioners see eye 
to eye.

	Doing a NEAT-style GP would be neet.  You have to define your domain a 
little, however.  ANN's only ever map floats onto floats and the only big 
strategic choice in how to do it is the recurrent/non-recurrent 
question.  This is a great advantage, because it means all ANN experiments 
are broadly comparable, which leads to a solid theoretical and intuitive 
grounding for the field as a whole.

	GP, in contrast, has more major tactical choices than there are people to 
make them.  You can have:
	- variables, or not,
	- data typing, or not,
		- casts or no casts
	- subroutines, or not,
	- indirect representations, or not,
	- maths operators (+, *, ...), logic operators (AND, OR), conditionals 
(IF, SELECT), trig, stats, ...
	- loops or no loops,
	- fixed constants, or evolving constants,
	- binary tree, mixed binary/unary, full N-ary

	etc etc

	Now, all that said, I think the case we're considering here is very simple:
	- all values are float
	- only arithmetic
	- no advanced features

	Is that right?  If so then it's a good experiment, but it is important to 
note that it only scratches the surface of what GP *could* do (not that 
it's very successful when it does, most successful applications tend to be 
in this area).

	Ian
